reviews.review_text: Age of Mythology is the classic, mythology based spinoff of Age of Empires, and boy was it fun. But does Age of Mythology Extended Edition live up to the original? In many ways, very much so, though the price tag might dissaude you unless you're a huge fan, (like I am).   If you've played Age of Mythology before, you know exactly how this game works. If not, here a basic gist of it. It plays much like Age of Empires 2; you have to collect resources, specifically food, wood and gold, in order to fund your armies, economies, technologies and advancement. sounds basic enough, and all the races work similarly in regards to these resources. The difference comes in the fourth resource: Favour. Favour is generated differently depending on which race you are playing. For instance, the greeks generate favour through worship, the egyptians through building monuments, the norse through heroes and fighting, and the atlanteans through having more settlements.   Favour is the special resource, which ties into the major mechanic of Age of Mythology: Gods and God Powers. There are 12 major gods, 3 for each of the races, and these determine starting bonuses for you when you start the game. the gods also have minor gods to choose each time you advance an age, with a total of 36 minor gods, each offering different bonuses and god powers. For instance Hades gives you the Sentinel God Power, that creates stone sentinels to watch over your town centre, but in the second age, you can choose Athena, who allows you to train minotaurs and the Restoration God power which can heal your units.  Aside from the new favour mechanic, for the major part it plays like the age of empires games. Build Army, upgrade, and take care of your population cap and economy. Rock paper scissors, for basic units, (cavalry beats archers who beat infantry), but add heroes and myth units which can turn the tide of battle. Both the singleplayer and multiplayer are fun, and with the new release, there is a rebirth in the multiplayer, though not as big as the heyday of AoM.   As being essentially a remake (a la Age of Empires 2 HD Edition), AoM:EE is actually fairly bug free, and while it definitely shows its age, the added subtle lighting effects, water and shadows do help to make look better. It is definitely very playable, and for fans of the original, it shouldn't even be a bother.  The campaign is just as memeroable as always, a hunt through Greece, Egypt, Scandinavia and finally Atlantis in order to stop a power hungry cyclops from releasing Kronos, King of the Titans; followed by A New Atlantis, set a number of years later,    where you are tricked into releasing the Titans, and must stop them at all costs   .   Overall, Age of Mythology: Extended Editon is fun, unique and offers up plenty of value, with 50 singleplayer missions, skrimishes, and now revived multiplayer, though for those who still have a copy of Age of Mythology and The Titans expansion, it might not add a great deal. Definitely recommend everyone else (who's a fan of older RTSes).

Age of Mythology: Extended Edition as a real-time strategy game published by Microsoft. It is a perfected version of the old game Age of Mythology and Age of Mythology: The Titans.  Age of Mythology: Extended Edition gameplay are pretty much the same as the old Age of Mythology and Age of Mythology: The Titans made into one game. In addition, the Golden Gift add on are also included in this remake. Unlike Age of Empires II: HD Edition, Age of Mythology: Extended Edition doesn't have population cap increase, everything in the gameplay stays the same. It's quite nostalgic to replay this old game with improved graphics, I remember almost all the god powers I used, the meteor rain, tornado, earthquake and more. Age of Mythology: Extended Edition also comes with Steam Cloud support and Steam Workshop support, which is a great addition into the game.  Age of Mythology: Extended Edition however, have improved graphics than the old game. New improved global lightning, widescreen support, new water shaders and the new day and night cycle in skirmish play. It looks prettier now and more epic to play. With all these improved visuals, Age of Mythology: Extended Edition still retain its great performances and runs very great and smooth.  Age of Mythology: Extended Edition exact same gameplay can be its good side or bad side for some people. But for me, it's very nostalgic and fun. I prefer this kind exact same gameplay rather than some of those next generation game with many promises which turn out to be a disappointment. Age of Mythology: Extended Edition is indeed a great remake. I recommend this.  Rating 9/10

Age of Mythology: Extended Edition is a good example of a poorly made cash grab. The Extended tag probably means the new bugs Skybox Labs managed to produce, that didn't exist in the original.  The AI pathfinding is messed up. Units often phase/clip through the walls and villagers often get stuck in larger buildings (Temple, Wonder, Titan Gate) they have finished building.  The changes to the graphics are highly questionable. The new textures are washed out and blurry, so it's highly recommended to revert them to something that looks closer to the original (EG: Epic textures mod). Otherwise you will have a hard time finding your units, as they blend into the environment too well.   Last but not least the netcode. Oh, boy! If you thought Age of Empires 2 HD's netcode was bad, then you have no idea what this game has in store for you. The online matches are insane lagfests, often freezing up for seconds, rendering the game unplayable.  Bottom line is that this version of the game is a mess. Skip it, you're not missing out much!

I got this game on 12/22/2016. After reading the numerous reviews about how I should not buy this game and play aom on voobly instead, I decided to go ahead and buy it anyway since I love aom (1800 rr back in 07' ;) ). I suppose I just was not satisfied because the reviews did not actually go into detail about anything that I thought was important. I am going to do my best, though, to give you the details of how terribly disappointing this game has been for me for the past couple days, even though I don't tend to give bad reviews because I don't like hurting other people's businesses, However, I consider this game a scam.I'm going to start with the China campaign, since that's where I started. The first issue arose when I restarted the first scenario, since I was kinda screwing around with looking at the new units and the AI got ahead of me. When I restarted, I was astonished to find that I was in the Archaic Age, rather than the Classical Age, like I had been in the game before. In addition, once I collected 400 food and built my first temple, I could not even advance to the Classical Age. Therefore, I was stuck trying to fight the AI with immortals from my town center, which was basically impossible once they started sending in human units. I restarted again and again, but could not resolve the issue. I decided to finally restart the whole game and wait out the cinematic all the way through again, and I finally got the game to start in the Classical Age. I can't say for sure that this bug exists within the game or if there is an issue with my computer. However, I reinstalled a fresh version of windows 8.1 about a week ago and there's basically nothing on my computer, so if it's a problem with my computer, then that's really a problem with poor compatability caused by the developers. The other possibility is it could be an issue caused by the Ekanta user interface mod that I dowloaded for, and I actually haven't tested that yet. However, Ekanta is a popular UI and I would be surprised if no one figured that out yet. After beating the first and the second scenarios, I got to the third, when I discovered that I once again could not advance to the classical age, despite having a temple and 400 food. I thought that this possibly could be like the original AOM campaign, which don't let you advance (although the option doesn't even show up for those), but was once again flooded by human units and forced to fight with the only unit I could make, which were immortals from my town center. This time I restarted and restarted and no matter what could not begin in whatever age i was supposed to, or resolve whatever the issue was this time. However, i couldn't advance, and did the only thing I could which was build my TC and either THRILL OF VICTORY, or spam O CANADA bears (recommend the O CANADA's if you run into this issue). I can't remember the order of the campaign past this because I just wanted to get it over with. Another one of the scenarios (there are only like 9 of these but they are almost all terrible) has you fight off an army. This time, when I restarted I discovered that my troops went from having heavy upgrades to having no upgrades. This bug has an easy fix, though, If you just restart and wait for part of the cinematic to finish before skipping; then your troops will once again be heavily armored. The final bug with the campaign that I ran into so far was once again that I could not age on another scenario, this time after building an armory since I actually started in the Classical Age. I was eventually able to beat the AI's champion, fully upgraded units with my clasical units after mixing in some monkey king myth units. So that ends most of what I want to say about the campaign. The final issue I want to bring up comes from watching a streamer play as thor against a chinese player in a 1v1. Once he got to the mythic age, he discovered that he mentioned that he had no units that could counter cataphract, which are Chinese counter-infantry cavalry, without also being countered by the cataphract themselves. Norse does not have an archer or a cavalry unit which counters cavalry, which would be the only two options, unless using myth units. Thanks for reading and please don't buy this game!

Summary - The Chinese expansion is rushed, copy-pasted from existing things, and glitchy. The people who profit from this are not the ones who made the original Age of Mythology.  Icons for Chinese buildings are re-used existing ones.  Chinese god powers and soldiers are like copies of existing ones, just changed a little bit. For example, the chinese monk is the egyptian priest with a different model, texture, icon and description, and instead of converting animals he converts enemies. He waves his arms and makes the exact same chant, and the cursor turns into an Egyprian Ankh when you mouse-over enemies.  Incorrect descriptions - The two Chinese heroes we start with are given Arkantos's description of special powers.  Poor story-telling - Unlike the original campaign, the beginning of the Chinese campaign has very little story-telling. You are not introduced to the gods, and you just start already in the second age. We only have a brief introduction to the heroes. At the beginning of the campaign... /(SPOILER)\ The heroes have to travel across China because when they realise there's evil afoot, a random peasant tells them to cross china, and so they do with no questions asked. \(SPOILER)/  Graphic glitches on my new-ish computer - You can see flames if the ground is behind them, but not if the sky if behind them. When placing walls. the wall segment that is behind another is drawn in front of what is actually in front of it.  Glitched first scenario in the Chinese campaign - You start in the Second age, but if you restart you are in the first age.  It runs slowly.  You can drag a box to select four soldiers and it will tell you you've selected only two, or the 'bamboo tree' nearby.  My fortified wall upgraded to an earthen wall.  I got a steam card of Thor with a really bad picture on it, with the description 'The Norse god of lightning'. Thor is the god of thunder, not lightning. Loki is the god of lightning.  This is my review after only getting to the second scenario in the Chinese campaign, because waiting to finish it to write the review would make it too late for the review to be helpful, because it's only just been released. Perhaps it's not their fault that the Chinese are so similar to the other ones, because there are only so many possibilities, and the three original races have already taken a share of the possibilities, but the lacking story-telling and the obviously reused artwork and code make it seem like the people who made it rushed it, or did not enjoy maknig it, or something like that. If it was released as a free mod then it would probably be well recieved, but it's been named an official expansion.

This game is an RTS, similar to Age of Empires and games like that. I used to paly this back in the day when it was new.  There are 4 cultures to pick from: Greek, Norse, Egyptian, and Atlantis. Pros:  - Fairly simple to understand and start playing - The campaigns are fun, and also teach you a little about mythological history (e.g. you have to collect a piece of Osiris in one of them) - The Single/Random maps can be a great way to kill a few minutes, or an hour - This version includes all the expansions/DLC - Voice acting is pretty good, even if the script's a little cheesy - The Devs are pretty active compared to a lot of other game communities  Cons:  - Last time I played this over LAN (and I mean THIS edition of the game), it was incredibly jerky. It didn't lag, but it did stutter. Totally playable, but not entirely fun. The latest patch apparently deals with this, but I haven't had time to test it and don't know when I will be able to again. - The extra lighting effects, while excellent, MAY mean that the game has a much higher 'minimum spec'. Having said that, most modern computers should be okay.

I admit I'm walking into this with extreme bias, that is due to the fact that I actually grew up with the rts genre before moving on to other types of gaming and only recently picking it up again. Also I before even purchasing this version already thought fondly of the game series, buying the extended edition twice due to losing one copy of it, and I was extremely young, therefore you could say I grew up on it.  Review Start:  This enhanced edition is pretty much a slightly prettier version of the vanilla game, that being said, the vanilla game is extremely strong. Just from one of the two vanilla stories, it's worth it's price tag, and there are 2 whole stories to it, a level editor, multiplayer.  There are problems with this version that weren't there in the previous versions.  For one, they took out the cheat codes, even in the vanilla story mode. I personally have fond memories of giant canadian caped flying bears who would shoot laser beams to take out the strongest of enemies, of running over building with giant 4 wheelers, and so forth, which actually takes away from the enjoyment heavily.  That being said, this game is still strong without the wackiness, it's a good way to get you interested in Greek Mythology like it did to me as a kid, and it's a solid rts game with decent balance and variances between the different religions/civilizations.   In reality, I would rank it as one of the better rts games to my knowledge, which is extremely dated and probably took place from 14 or so years ago up to around 7 years ago. I consider this game only second to the Battle for Middle Earth series and it's deeply ingrained into my childhood.  The characters are never really all that fleshed out even though you're supposed to have an attachment to the characters, especially the villains who seem like named canon fodder hero enemies, but the troops are all fairly unique to each other, even though you'll almost never be using human troops even fully upgraded in later ages (progression system in specific matches)  Overall it's a solid game that's worth trying out, but the enhanced edition doesn't actually enhance anything but the water and day and night cycle when it would have been interesting to have myth troops. If you're a completionist, you'll enjoy the achievements, if you want a solid rts with an interesting theme and fun dynamics to different cultures, this is a good buy. If you're a psychopath like me, you'll also enjoy level editor where you'll talk like you're the characters and make your own story.  7/10 Masterpiece when viewed with nostalgia.
